items.title: chardetect.exe - usage
items.body: Hi - I see the executable "chardetect.exe" gets installed under the "Scripts" directory in my virtual environment.  Let me know how this is used.  Also, do I need it when I install this dependency in an aws lambda layer?

items.title: should the shebang be removed?
items.body:
cli/chardetect.py has shebang "#!/usr/bin/env python",  on some host,  like fedora31 docker image, 
only python3 installed,  and no python link to python3, in this case,  maybe error like "python: command not found" will repored when run it.

items.title: Encoding of an *asf file
items.body:
I don't know if this topic fits here but I'm stuck with a file with an extension *.asf. An example can be found here: [http://www.ftirsearch.com/Demo/demo_data.asp](url).
With the free version of [https://www.essentialftir.com/index.html](url), I can convert it manually with the eftir tool but I want to make a script to convert a lot of *.asf files to *.csv files. Is there anybody who can help me with the encoding of this *.asf file format? Thanks in advance

items.title: Offering to help with the project
items.body:
I've noticed that activity on this project has slowed, and I was wondering if you needed some help. Would you consider adding the project to [Code Shelter](https://www.codeshelter.co/)? It's an open community of open source maintainers (please feel free to join!) that aims to help OSS projects out (fixing bugs, merging PRs, releasing, etc), and I'm a member and can help.

You can [read more details about it](https://www.codeshelter.co/faq/) or [add your project](https://www.codeshelter.co/projects/add/) to it.

items.title: A typo and inconsistent case for language names
items.body:
There is a typo in the language name of ISO-8859-5 Bulgarian model. (Bulgairan -> Bulgarian)

In the doc, all encoding names starting with "windows-" are lowercase, but "Windows-1253" is titlecased.

items.body:

There are occasional "no module named 'universaldetector'" messages that arise when chardet is installed as part of an aiohttp installation on [Pythonista](http://omz-software.com/pythonista) on iOS.  Does anyone know an effective workaround for this issue?

Hello.

What are the different tricks used to try to detect an encoding ?

which gives?

items.title: Kill Python 2.6 (and maybe Python 3.3?)
items.body:
Python 2.6 support can be removed for future releases.  No modern project uses 2.6 and also does library upgrades so it seems that it would be best to just stop testing 2.6 so that code can be written without 2.6 workarounds.

I would also advocate for 3.3 removal since 3.4 was released 3 years ago.  This helps keep things clean.

I'm happy to make a PR if there's agreement on removing these versions from the tests/setup.

items.title: Release 3.0.3 lacks some commits
items.body:
chardet-3.0.3.tar.gz on PyPI lacks at least https://github.com/chardet/chardet/commit/b874c25b08edd6bdbdd70a439c6cd603d6830226 commit, that fixes pytest dependency issue. Can you confirm this?

When are you going to release 3.0.4?

prints False

No matter how large a document is fed to UniversalDetector it never gets done.

items.title: Empty language in results
items.body:
I run simple code on my files

```
import glob
from chardet.universaldetector import UniversalDetector

detector = UniversalDetector()
for filename in glob.glob('**/*.csv', recursive=True):
    print(filename.ljust(60))
    detector.reset()
    for line in open(filename, 'rb'):
        detector.feed(line)
        if detector.done: break
    detector.close()
    print(detector.result)
```

But all results have empty language field (actually it is russian)

```
(.env) [olabs@hera storage]$ python encodig_detection.py 
azbuka_vkusa/loaded/turnover/MDC-108-17-04-16-04-46-26-062.csv
{'language': '', 'encoding': 'utf-8', 'confidence': 0.99}
azbuka_vkusa/loaded/turnover/MDC-108-17-04-15-09-11-39-185.csv
{'language': '', 'encoding': 'utf-8', 'confidence': 0.99}

{'language': '', 'encoding': 'utf-8', 'confidence': 0.99}

{'language': '', 'encoding': 'utf-8', 'confidence': 0.99}

{'language': '', 'encoding': 'utf-8', 'confidence': 0.99}

{'language': '', 'encoding': 'utf-8', 'confidence': 0.99}
```

items.title: chardet 3.0.0 breaks the behavior of 2.3.0 without a depreciation notice.
items.body:
hello, I was trying to solve a issue in [`binaryornot`](https://github.com/audreyr/binaryornot) https://github.com/pydanny/cookiecutter-django/issues/1118#issuecomment-293578836

Is expected that the `chardet.detect()` function return a dictionary with `encoding` and `confidence` keys. However, `None` is being returned for some cases.

The cases in question is if I try to detect the encoding of the first 1024 bytes of images files. (I do not know if there are other cases like that.)

The question is: Is this the expected result, is a issue or is a documentation issue?

From this snippet and this [sample_images.zip](https://github.com/chardet/chardet/files/917307/sample_images.zip):

```python
import chardet

print('chardet version:', chardet.__version__)

def detect_from_file(filename, length=1024):
    first_chunk_of_file = None
    with open(filename, 'rb') as f:
        first_chunk_of_file = f.read(length)
        detected_encoding = chardet.detect(first_chunk_of_file)
        return detected_encoding


images = ['bmp_format.bmp', 'gif_format.gif', 'jpg_format.jpg', 'png_format.png', 'tga_format.tga']

for i in images:
    c = detect_from_file(i)
    print('____\nfile: {}'.format(i))
    print(c, '\n')

```

##### Chardet 3.0.1 return:

```bash
chardet version: 3.0.1
____
file: bmp_format.bmp
{'encoding': 'ISO-8859-1', 'confidence': 0.73, 'language': ''} 

____
file: gif_format.gif
None 

____
file: jpg_format.jpg
None 

____
file: png_format.png
None 

____
file: tga_format.tga
{'encoding': 'ISO-8859-1', 'confidence': 0.73, 'language': ''}
```


##### but the expected values to return is

```bash
chardet version: 2.3.0
____
file: bmp_format.bmp
{'encoding': 'windows-1252', 'confidence': 0.73} 

____
file: gif_format.gif
{'encoding': None, 'confidence': 0.0} 

____
file: jpg_format.jpg
{'encoding': 'ISO-8859-2', 'confidence': 0.2766991521036145} 

____
file: png_format.png
{'encoding': 'IBM866', 'confidence': 0.345640381912402} 

____
file: tga_format.tga
{'encoding': 'windows-1252', 'confidence': 0.73}
```

UnicodeDecodeError: 'charmap' codec can't decode byte 0x90 in position 51: character maps to <undefined>

items.title: Cleaning up unit tests
items.body:
It would be good to get the build to be green.

Should we separate out the failing tests into a folder where we keep failing tests (e.g. files that are known not to don't dected correctly), but only run these tests _exceptionally_  - e.g. during development testing with a flag?  

They could be aspirational targets to detect successfully. :)

items.title: CP949 detected for what used to be ASCII
items.body:
Thank you for putting this package together and going through the hassle of merging these versions. Sounds like you've been busy!

I maintain [textract](https://github.com/deanmalmgren/textract) and we've recently had a few issues where the encoding detection is not working as well as it once did (e.g. https://github.com/deanmalmgren/textract/issues/107, https://github.com/deanmalmgren/textract/issues/133, and https://github.com/deanmalmgren/textract/issues/135) . When I revert back to version `2.1.1`, I am successfully able to detect that the file mentioned in https://github.com/deanmalmgren/textract/issues/107 is ASCII encoded. Later versions describe it as CP949, which causes problems for textract.

I would be happy to help address this issue. I am not familiar with the chardet codebase, so if you could point me in the right direction, that would be great. In the meantime, I can pin the version to chardet 2.1.1 which should hopefully resolve the issue in the interim.

testfile.GB2312.cs is the RIGHT.

items.body:
Hi Guys,
   Does this return information about the line feed of a file e.g.
LF+CR
LF
CR
CR+LF

items.title: ISO-8859-1 not mentioned in documentation
items.body:
I presume this is because it's covered by Windows 1252, but whereas other ISO-8859 encodings are mentioned next to their Windows superset, ISO-8859-1 is not.

If in fact the issue is more subtle, that would also be worth documenting!

items.title: Please do not remove old versions from pypi
items.body:
Hi,

I notice that older versions (pre-2.3.0) have been removed from https://pypi.python.org/pypi/chardet 

Removing older versions will break people's deployments. Could you please keep this in mind when making new releases?

Thanks in advance,

Kees

items.title: ISO-8859-1 being detect as Windows-1252
items.body:
Sorry if there is already an issue related to this, but I'm not sure what is cause yet.

I've got an `ISO-8859-1` string detected as `Windows-1252`, although those two encoding differ in only 32 characters, `mystring.decode('windows-1252')` fail to decode the content, that's why I'm filing this issue.

If you need a test case you can query whois data for `brasil.gov.br` the string will contain `ISO-8859-1` encoded data however will be detect as `Windows-1252` with 99% confidence.

items.title: PyPi package is not up to date
items.body:
Hi! I just compared your github codebase to the your PyPi package (installed via pip) and noticed that the code there seems to be out of date (even though it gives the same version number).

Would be cool to have an up-to-date version on pypi since there's a problem with ascii escape sequences in the pypi package that doesn't seem to exist with the github version :)

items.title: Is it OK to replace GB2312 by GB18030?
items.body:
From wiki:
Like UTF-8, GB18030 is a superset of ASCII and can represent the whole range of Unicode code points; in addition, it is also a superset of GB2312.

If GB18030 is a superset of GB2312, is it OK to replace GB2312 by GB18030?

items.title: Misdetection of utf-8 as ISO-8859-2 for german umlauts
items.body:
Version: chardetect-script.py 2.3.0 on Windows environment; Python 3.4.3 (native) and in Cygwin shell (same in other shells)
Here the content of the misdetected script:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python3
# coding: utf-8
#
################################################################################

__version__ = '1.0'
__author__ = 'ü'
```

output of chardet:

```
$ chardetect uu.py 
uu.py: ISO-8859-2 with confidence 0.7916670185186749
```

output of file (Cygwin):

```
$ file uu.py 
uu.py: a /usr/bin/env python3 script, UTF-8 Unicode text executable, with CRLF line terminators
```

If i read the problematic line by `open(file, 'rb').readlines()` i get 
`b"__author__ = '\xc3\xbc'\r\n"`

Am i getting something wrong?


This one doesn't actually come from Hypothesis but from a fuzzing experiment I was running which it occurred to me would be applicable to chardet.

items.title: Escape control character also prevents detection in utf-8
items.body:
The following has no encoding detected:

``` python
u'\u020d\x1b'.encode('utf-8')
```

Again, not a length issue. Padding with ascii doesn't change anything. The initial character _is_ needed, I believe purely because it prevents the fix in #63 from applying by preventing the string from being considered as ascii.

Behaviour is present in 9e419e9b411a15e26c5542968b6daa3fbb4c672d

items.title: ASCII escape control character prevents detection of encoding
items.body:
It appears to be the case that the presence of '\x1b' character (the escape key) in an ascii string prevents it from being recognised as ascii. e.g. for any n the following returns an encoding of None:

``` python
b'0' * n + b'\x1b'
```

This behaviour is present in master at ff1d9173dc4304899d6aa982d3a12f171a82da1c

items.title: failed to detect utf8 "FAHR•WERK"
get wrong codec
items.body:
I use chardet to detect the codec of the 'Cinecitt%C3%A0%20Make', like this

``` python
import urlparse
import chardet
a = 'Cinecitt%C3%A0%20Make'
b = urlparse.unquote(a)
chardet.detect(b)
```

the result is {'confidence': 0.814286076190637, 'encoding': 'ISO-8859-2'}
but '%c3%a0' is an utf8 code of character 'à'
is there something wrong?

items.title: Chardet returns ISO-8859 when cp1252 is better
items.body:
Ages ago, [I filed a bug that got erroneously closed by a commit](https://github.com/dcramer/chardet/issues/8). I just stumbled on it again today, so I'm moving it over from the old location so we can see about getting it going again. 

Here's the text of the old bug:

> I had a frustrating issue recently when trying to use chardet to work with a web page: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11588458/how-to-handle-encodings-using-python-requests-library
> 
> My solution was to write a bit of custom code that says, "Whenever chardet reports ISO-8859-1, instead use cp1252." It would be great if chardet internalized this behavior.
> 
> Basically, browsers don't use a number of character encodings, and instead map to other ones instead. Since most of the data that chardet is used on will be coming from the web, it makes sense for it to return the character encodings that are used by browsers. 
> 
> This might make sense as an option rather than default functionality....not sure, but I'd love to see this be added.

Is there still an appetite for this kind of an issue? Basically, I think—and ages ago, committer @dan-blanchard agreed—that chardet should never return ISO-8859 and should always return cp1252 instead.

items.title: Issue with invoking chardet with IronPython: 'Expected a bytes object, not an unicode object'
items.body:
Due to the way IronPython 2.7.5 natively handles strings, I'm encountering errors with passing arguments to chardet's __init__ in third-party packages using chardet (requests for example).

Specifically, this section of code causes problematic behaviour:

```
def detect(byte_str):
    if (PY2 and isinstance(byte_str, unicode)) or (PY3 and
                                               not isinstance(byte_str,
                                                              bytes)):
        raise ValueError('Expected a bytes object, not a unicode object')
```

Can we perhaps add some way of detecting if we're using IronPython and then a check in __init__, which would pass bytes(string) to u.feed() instead?

For instance, in compat.py:

```
import platform

if (platform.python_implementation() == 'IronPython'):
    IPY = True
else:
    IPY = False
```

in __init__.py:

```
from compat import IPY
if (PY2 and not IPY and isinstance(byte_str, unicode)) or (PY3 or IPY and not isinstance(byte_str, bytes)):
    raise ValueError('Expected a bytes object, not a unicode object')
```

items.title: Upgrading from oldish version
items.body:
Hi guys,

I recently took over a project that make use of chardet @ 73ab96363edcad26a9f59e240c0c073a34ba4f88 which I guess is 1.1.

Do you have any pointer on big breaking changes since then I should be aware of?

Thx !

items.title: Failing to guess a single MS-apostrophe
items.body:
I have a page of text in ASCII with a single Microsoft-apostrophe `chr(8217)` detected as **ISO-8859-2**. 

``` python
#1. Create problematic sample
>>> s = 'today' + chr(8217) + 's research'
>>> s
'today’s research'
>>> b = s.encode('windows-1252')
>>> b
b'today\x92s research'

#2. Attempt to decode it
>>> chardet.detect(b)
{'encoding': 'ISO-8859-2', 'confidence': 0.8060609643099236}
>>> b.decode('ISO-8859-2')
'today\x92s research'

#3. Now try the correct encoding
>>> b.decode('windows-1252')
'today’s research'
```

This text is very typical of anything created using a Microsoft editor. Furthermore, latest version of Firefox detects it correctly. I am using Python 3.3. Any help is appreciated.

items.title: filter_with_english_letters
items.body:
Currently, this function has been listed as a TO-DO. I was looking over at the source from Mozilla and it seems that there could be a bug in that. 

From what I can tell, the original intention of this function was to remove all markup tags. Its used in the LatinProber and I imagine that the idea is to remove all markup tags - which will probably contain english alphabets/words - so that we can avoid skewing our confidence incorrectly. 

The current behavior though is not that. A simple example: 

```
<some tag> outside <some tag>
```

returns

```
tag outside tag
```

It includes parts of text within a tag if there are multiple words separated by any kind of punctuation in the tag. I can look into this, by I wanted to know your thoughts on this first?

items.title: Potential changes to filter_without_english_characters?
items.body: I noticed that the filter_without_english_characters function in chardet simply replaces any english alphabetical character with a space character. This might lead to inaccuracies in our confidence. I tried mimicking the behavior of Mozilla's implementation more closely and this led to a decrease in the count of failing unit tests from 28 to 25. I wanted to know your thoughts on this and you can also check out my changes over here. .

items.title: Rename main branches to prevent commons pull request target mistake
items.body:
I'm just putting this here as an announcement that I will shortly be renaming the main branches as follows:
-  `master` :arrow_right: `stable`
-  `develop` :arrow_right: `master`

This should prevent the common problem where people don't change the target to `develop` even though we're trying to use git-flow.

items.title: Inconsistent behavior on small strings
items.body:
**UPD**: Deleted python2.7 example because it was not working properly. See [a comment below](https://github.com/chardet/chardet/issues/37#issuecomment-63086584) for a better test case.

This is all on Debian GNU/Linux unstable with the current master:

```
$ python3.4 -c "import chardet; print(chardet.detect(u'é'.encode('utf-8')))"
{'confidence': 0.73, 'encoding': 'windows-1252'}
$ python3.4 -c "import chardet; print(chardet.detect(u'éé'.encode('utf-8')))"
{'confidence': 0.7525, 'encoding': 'utf-8'}
```

The second line should be `utf-8` as well, not `windows-1252`.

items.title: Changing license
items.body:
This feels strange to be posing as a question, since I'm one of the co-maintainers, but @sigmavirus24 and @erikrose, do you know if it's okay/legal for us to change the license of chardet?  Because it was started by Mark Pilgrim I feel like it's kind of a nebulous question, because he's not someone you can just email, and he has nothing to do with development anymore.  I would really like to change the license to at least be MPL, since that's what the C++ version is, and our setup currently mirrors that code pretty closely. 

I'm not a fan of the LGPL and feel weird having a project I work on use it.

items.title: UTF-8 + win EOL + 1st empty string = error
items.body:
I have a file in UTF-8 with BOM with Dos\Windows lines end and first string empty:

EF BB BF 0D 0A 23 69 6E .......(text)

info  = chardet.detect(raw)
# info {'confidence': 0.7821182921733318, 'encoding': 'ISO-8859-2'}

There is error with Unix line end (\n) also :(

It's needed to say, that I read file this way:
file_open = open(file_path, "r")  # rb also error
raw = file_open.read()

Python 2.7.6 (default, Nov 10 2013, 19:24:18) [MSC v.1500 32 bit (Intel)] on win32

items.title: Can not distinguish UTF-8 and UTF-8-SIG
items.body:
I tried to change the universaldetector.py file, but it still returned utf-8.

``` python
            if aBuf[:3] == codecs.BOM:
                # EF BB BF  UTF-8 with BOM
                self.result = {'encoding': "UTF-8-SIG", 'confidence': 1.0}
```

Output:

```
>>> chardet.detect(open('test.txt').read())
{'confidence': 0.99, 'encoding': 'utf-8'}
```

items.title: multiple detection failures with 2.2.1
items.body:
Using d5d0812423893, I am seeing multiple failues to correctly detect utf-8. Some examples: "gebührenfrei", "exámple", "naïve", "sie hören", "This is a cat 😸". (Strings that are ASCII except for a single character seem to be particularly troublesome.)

See also sigmavirus24/charade#24, sigmavirus24/charade#25. d5d0812423893 seems to be doing slightly "better" than python-chardet-2.0.1-7.fc20.noarch, for what it's worth (fewer confidence = 0.99 detections, though still wrong).

I also see 27 failed unit tests. Please let me know if this is known and/or if I should paste the complete error log here.

items.title: LGPL and iPhone
items.body:
Had an "interesting" discussion in the Stackoverflow Python room ([bookmarked transcript here](http://chat.stackoverflow.com/rooms/6/conversation/chardet-and-lgpl))

There's an article [compatibility between the iphone and lgpl](http://multinc.com/2009/08/24/compatibility-between-the-iphone-app-store-and-the-lgpl/) that has some analysis as well as links to other resources, but it appears there's not really a conclusion except the owner could assert rights, but in the spirit of things most likely wouldn't...

I'm just wondering what the stance is from the author(s) here?

items.title: Reformat docs into Sphinx format
items.body:
Since this project was created, Sphinx has become the de-facto standard for publishing [Python] documentation on the web.

Thus, should reformat docs into Sphinx format

https://github.com/chardet/chardet/issues/23

items.title: Host the docs on the web
items.body:
The docs from https://github.com/chardet/chardet/tree/master/docs should be hosted on a web site, to make them more accessible.

https://readthedocs.org/ maybe?

items.title: Turkish (iso-8859-9) detecting.
items.body:
I want to help for Turkish language detection but I don't understand what order or how I supposed to put things to lang*model.py.

Turkish is Latin5 8-bit single-byte coded Language
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO-8859-9
http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/ECMA-ST/Ecma-128.pdf (code table is on page 16)

items.title: Provide classifiers for PyPI that specify which Python versions chardet supports
text encoding detected as windows-1255 (hebrew) while being windows-1252
items.body:
With a certain file, charted detects encoding as windows-1255. I would have thought it might be the file itself but my IDE for python development detected the encoding properly.
File link:
http://simple.podnapisi.net/fr/ppodnapisi/download/i/2292027/k/b5a3b7904326647fce0270ef3f441de7b73663af
